message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest renal cell carcinoma. Among the options, only option B describes a malignant feature of a urothelial tumor, which is consistent with renal pelvis cancer. Options A, C, and D describe different types of tumors that are not typically associated with renal pelvis cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and CT findings suggest renal pelvic transitional cell carcinoma, which is most likely to show a pedunculated tumor comprised of pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia. Option A describes a colonic adenocarcinoma, which is not associated with the renal pelvis. Option C describes a renal oncocytoma, which is a benign tumor. Option D describes a Wilms tumor, which is rare in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan findings suggest renal cell carcinoma, which commonly arises from the renal tubular cells. Among the options, only (B) describes a tumor comprised of pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia, which can be seen in renal pelvis tumors. Ulcerating glandular cells and mucinous material suggest adenocarcinoma, not renal cell carcinoma. Bright yellow cells filled with lipids and glycogen suggest clear cell carcinoma, while primitive blastemal cells forming abortive glomeruli suggest Wilms tumor, both of which are less likely than urothelial carcinoma in the renal pelvis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of dark urine and weight loss, along with a CT scan showing a mass arising from the left renal pelvis, suggest urothelial carcinoma. The pedunculated tumor with severe nuclear atypia is consistent with this type of cancer. The other answer choices do not match the expected pathology of urothelial carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a heterogeneous enhancing mass arising from the renal pelvis suggests a renal pelvis tumor. Among the options, only option B describes a pedunculated tumor comprising pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia, which is most likely to be found on pathologic examination of a urothelial carcinoma arising from the renal pelvis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the CT scan suggest renal cell carcinoma. Among the options, only (B) describes a malignant tumor arising from the urothelium of the renal pelvis, which is the most likely finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the CT scan suggest a renal pelvis mass, which is most likely to be urothelial cell carcinoma. Option B describes the most likely pathologic finding for this type of cancer. Option A describes adenocarcinoma, which is less common in this location. Option C describes renal cell carcinoma, which arises from the renal parenchyma. Option D describes Wilms tumor, which is typically found in children younger than 5 years old.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass as arising from the left renal pelvis suggests that this is a renal pelvis tumor, and the weight loss and smoking history raise the suspicion for malignancy. Among the options, only option (B) describes a malignant tumor arising from the renal pelvis- a pedunculated tumor comprised of pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia. Option (A) describes a tumor that is glandular in nature and not typically associated with the renal pelvis, while options (C) and (D) describe tumors that are not typically associated with the renal pelvis or with malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest renal cell carcinoma, and among the options, only option B describes a pedunculated tumor with pleomorphic urothelial cells and severe nuclear atypia, which are characteristic of urothelial carcinoma of the renal pelvis. Option A describes adenocarcinoma, which is not common in the renal pelvis. Option C describes an oncocytoma, which is usually benign. Option D describes Wilms tumor, which is more common in children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, smoking history, and CT scan findings suggest a left renal mass. Among the options, only answer choice B describes a malignant tumor arising from the urothelium, which is consistent with a urothelial carcinoma arising from the renal pelvis. Answer choice A describes an adenocarcinoma arising from the kidney or ureter. Answer choice C describes a renal oncocytoma, which is a benign tumor. Answer choice D describes a Wilms tumor, which is typically seen in pediatric patients.
